text: I am a man. Over the past two weeks, I have never had little interest or pleasure in doing things. I have felt down, depressed, or hopeless more than half the days. I have had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much more than half the days. I have never felt tired or having little energy. I have never had poor appetite or overeaten. I have never felt bad about myself — or that I am a failure or have let myself or my family down. I have never had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television. I have never moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed. I have never had thoughts that I would be better off dead or of hurting myself in some way. Do i have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No'

I am a man. Over the past two weeks, I have never had little interest or pleasure in doing things. I have felt down, depressed, or hopeless more than half the days. I have had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much more than half the days. I have never felt tired or having little energy. I have never had poor appetite or overeaten. I have never felt bad about myself — or that I am a failure or have let myself or my family down. I have never had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television. I have never moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed. I have never had thoughts that I would be better off dead or of hurting myself in some way. Do i have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: No.  While you have experienced some symptoms commonly associated with depression, such as feeling down, depressed, or hopeless, and having trouble with sleep, you do not meet the full criteria for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder. According to the DSM-5, a diagnosis of major depressive disorder requires at least five of the following symptoms to be present for at least two weeks, with at least one of the symptoms being either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan

model_completion: No.  Based on the information provided, he does not meet the criteria for major depressive disorder. While he has experienced poor appetite or overeating nearly every day and has felt bad about himself several days, he does not exhibit the other key symptoms of depression such as persistent sadness, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, sleep disturbances, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, or suicidal thoughts. For a diagnosis of major depressive disorder, a person typically needs to experience at least five of the specified symptoms nearly every day for at least two weeks, and these symptoms must cause significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: No. While he does exhibit some symptoms that can be associated with depression, such as feeling tired or having little energy nearly every day and having thoughts of self-harm several days, he does not meet the full criteria for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder. According to the DSM-5, a diagnosis of major depressive disorder requires at least five of the following symptoms to be present nearly every day for at least two weeks, with at least one of the symptoms being either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt

model_completion: Yes. These include:  1. Little interest or pleasure in doing things (anhedonia) several days. 2. Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless nearly every day. 3. Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much several days. 4. Feeling bad about himself or feeling like a failure nearly every day. 5. Moving or speaking slowly several days.  While he does not exhibit all possible symptoms of depression (such as fatigue, poor appetite, or suicidal thoughts), the presence of multiple significant symptoms nearly every day for at least two weeks suggests that he may be experiencing a depressive episode. It is important for him to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others). 6. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 7. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The individual described has experienced several of these symptoms, including diminished interest or pleasure, feelings of worthlessness, changes in sleep patterns, changes in appetite, psychomotor retardation, and recurrent thoughts of death or self-harm. These symptoms have been present for more than two weeks, which meets the duration criterion for MDD. Therefore, it is appropriate to conclude that he likely has depression. However

He has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much several days. He has never felt tired or having little energy. He has had poor appetite or overeaten more than half the days. He has felt bad about himself — or that he am a failure or have let himself or his family down nearly every day. He has had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television several days. He has never moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed. He has had thoughts that he would be better off dead or of hurting himself in some way several days. Does he have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 6. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 7. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The individual described has experienced most of these symptoms nearly every day for the past two weeks, which suggests a diagnosis of depression. However, a formal diagnosis should be made by a qualified mental health professional.

model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align with several key criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These include:  1. Little interest or pleasure in doing things. 2. Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless. 3. Trouble with sleep (either insomnia or hypersomnia). 4. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt. 5. Psychomotor changes (moving or speaking slowly). 6. Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide.  While not all symptoms of MDD are present (e.g., fatigue, poor appetite, or concentration issues), the presence of multiple significant symptoms, especially the thoughts of self-harm, strongly suggests that he may be experiencing depression. It is important for him to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. He is a man. Over the past two weeks, he has never had little interest or pleasure in doing things. He has felt down, depressed, or hopeless nearly every day. He has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much more than half the days. He has felt tired or having little energy several days. He has never had poor appetite or overeaten. He has felt bad about himself — or that he am a failure or have let himself or his family down nearly every day. He has never had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television. He has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed more than half the days. He has had thoughts that he would be better off dead or of hurting himself in some way nearly every day. Does he have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 4. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 5. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 6. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others). 7. Recurrent thoughts of death or suicidal ideation.  The individual described has experienced most of these symptoms nearly every day for the past two weeks, which suggests a diagnosis of depression. It is important for him to seek professional help for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment.

He is a man. Over the past two weeks, he has had little interest or pleasure in doing things nearly every day. He has felt down, depressed, or hopeless several days. He has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much several days. He has felt tired or having little energy more than half the days. He has had poor appetite or overeaten more than half the days. He has felt bad about himself — or that he am a failure or have let himself or his family down nearly every day. He has never had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television. He has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed nearly every day. He has had thoughts that he would be better off dead or of hurting himself in some way nearly every day. Does he have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The individual described has experienced many of these symptoms nearly every day for the past two weeks, which suggests a diagnosis of depression. However, a formal diagnosis should be made by a qualified mental health professional.

Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others). 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The individual described has experienced many of these symptoms nearly every day or more than half the days over the past two weeks, which suggests a diagnosis of depression. It is important for him to seek professional help for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment

Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. model_completion: Yes. The presence of these symptoms nearly every day for at least two weeks suggests that he may be experiencing a major depressive episode. It is important for him to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Given the severity and frequency of these symptoms, it is likely that he is experiencing depression. However, a formal diagnosis should be made by a qualified mental health professional.

Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The individual described has exhibited more than five of these symptoms, including depressed

He has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much more than half the days. He has felt tired or having little energy nearly every day. He has had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television nearly every day. He has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed several days. He has had thoughts that he would be better off dead or of hurting himself in some way nearly every day. Does he have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes. The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include a persistent depressed mood, loss of interest or pleasure in most activities, significant changes in sleep and appetite, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt, difficulty concentrating, psychomotor changes, and recurrent thoughts of death or suicide. Given the duration and severity of these symptoms, it is highly likely that he is experiencing depression. However, a formal diagnosis should be made by a qualified mental health professional.

model_completion: Yes. The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). The presence of these symptoms nearly every day for at least two weeks suggests that he may be experiencing a major depressive episode. It is important for him to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

He has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much nearly every day. He has felt tired or having little energy more than half the days. He has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed nearly every day. He has had thoughts that he would be better off dead or of hurting himself in some way nearly every day. model_completion: Yes. The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include a persistent depressed mood, loss of interest or pleasure in most activities, significant changes in sleep and appetite, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt, difficulty concentrating, psychomotor changes, and recurrent thoughts of death or suicide. The presence of these symptoms nearly every day for at least two weeks suggests that he may be experiencing a major depressive episode. It is important for him to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

model_completion: Yes. It is important for him to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, or a suicide attempt. model_completion: Yes. Given the duration and severity of these symptoms, it is highly likely that he is experiencing depression. It is important for him to seek professional help for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment.

He has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much nearly every day. He has felt tired or having little energy nearly every day. He has had poor appetite or overeaten nearly every day. He has never felt bad about himself — or that he am a failure or have let himself or his family down. He has had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television more than half the days. He has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed nearly every day. He has had thoughts that he would be better off dead or of hurting himself in some way nearly every day. Does he have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 8. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The individual described has experienced most of these symptoms nearly every day for the past two weeks, which suggests a diagnosis of depression. However, a formal diagnosis should be made by a qualified mental health professional.

model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align with several key criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These include:  1. Depressed mood (feeling down, depressed, or hopeless). 2. Anhedonia (little interest or pleasure in doing things). 3. Sleep disturbances (trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much). 4. Fatigue or loss of energy. 5. Changes in appetite (poor appetite or overeating). 6. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt. 7. Recurrent thoughts of death or suicidal ideation.  While she does not exhibit all possible symptoms (e.g., trouble concentrating, psychomotor changes), the presence of multiple significant symptoms over a two-week period suggests a diagnosis of depression. It is important for her to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

It is important for her to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described suggest that she may be experiencing depression. According to the DSM-5 criteria for Major Depressive Disorder, a person must have at least five of the following symptoms for a two-week period, and at least one of the symptoms must be either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. model_completion: No.  While she exhibits some symptoms that can be associated with depression, such as a lack of interest or pleasure in activities, sleep disturbances, poor appetite, and feelings of worthlessness, she does not meet the full criteria for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder. According to the DSM-5, a diagnosis of major depressive disorder requires at least five symptoms to be present nearly every day for at least two weeks, and one of the symptoms must be either a depressed mood or a loss of interest or pleasure in most activities. Additionally, the symptoms must cause significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning. In this case, she has not felt down, depressed, or hopeless, and she does not have enough symptoms to meet the full criteria for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder. However, her thoughts of self-harm are concerning and should be addressed by a mental health professional.

Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. model_completion: Yes.  Based on the symptoms described, she meets several criteria for a diagnosis of depression. According to the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition), a major depressive episode is characterized by at least five of the following symptoms, present during the same 2-week period, and representing a change from previous functioning, with at least one of the symptoms being either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  She has

model_completion: Yes. The symptoms described align with the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include experiencing at least five of the following symptoms over a two-week period, with at least one of the symptoms being either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others). 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The woman described has experienced at least five of these symptoms,

It is important for her to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others). 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.  She exhibits many of these symptoms, including a depressed mood, loss of interest or pleasure, sleep disturbances, fatigue, changes in appetite, feelings of worthlessness, and difficulty concentrating. Although she does not have suicidal thoughts, the presence of multiple other symptoms suggests she may be experiencing depression. It is important for her to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

She has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much more than half the days. She has felt tired or having little energy nearly every day. She has had poor appetite or overeaten more than half the days. She has felt bad about herself — or that she am a failure or have let herself or her family down several days. She has had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television several days. She has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed nearly every day. She has had thoughts that she would be better off dead or of hurting herself in some way several days. Does she have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The presence of these symptoms for more than half the days over the past two weeks suggests that she may be experiencing a depressive episode. It is important for her to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

She has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much more than half the days. She has felt tired or having little energy more than half the days. She has never had poor appetite or overeaten. She has felt bad about herself — or that she am a failure or have let herself or her family down nearly every day. She has never had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television. She has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed more than half the days. She has had thoughts that she would be better off dead or of hurting herself in some way nearly every day. Does she have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day (not applicable in this case). 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day (not applicable in this case). 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The individual described has experienced most of these symptoms nearly every day for the past two weeks, which suggests a diagnosis of depression. However, a formal diagnosis should be made by a qualified mental health professional

These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The presence of these symptoms, particularly the depressed mood, loss of interest or pleasure, changes in sleep and appetite, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, difficulty concentrating, psychomotor changes, and suicidal thoughts, strongly suggest that she may be experiencing Major Dep

Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. Given the frequency and severity of these symptoms, it is likely that you are experiencing depression. It is important to seek professional help for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment.

model_completion: Yes. Given the duration and severity of these symptoms, it is highly likely that she is experiencing depression. It is important for her to seek professional help for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment.

model_completion: Yes. These criteria include experiencing at least five of the following symptoms for a minimum of two weeks, with at least one of the symptoms being either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide. She is a woman. Over the past two weeks, she has had little interest or pleasure in doing things nearly every day. She has felt down, depressed, or hopeless nearly every day. She has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much nearly every day. She has felt tired or having little energy several days. She has had poor appetite or overeaten nearly every day. She has felt bad about herself — or that she am a failure or have let herself or her family down several days. She has had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television more than half the days. She has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed several days. She has had thoughts that she would be better off dead or of hurting herself in some way nearly every day. Does she have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The presence of these symptoms, particularly the thoughts of death or self-harm, indicates that she may be experiencing a major depressive episode. It is important for her to seek professional help for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment.

model_completion: Yes. The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). The presence of these symptoms nearly every day for at least two weeks suggests a diagnosis of depression. It is important for her to seek professional help for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment.

model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt. 8. model_completion: Yes. The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD) as outlined in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition). These criteria include experiencing at least five of the following symptoms over a two-week period, with at least one of the symptoms being either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The woman described has experienced many of these symptoms, including depressed mood, loss

She is a woman. Over the past two weeks, she has had little interest or pleasure in doing things more than half the days. She has felt down, depressed, or hopeless several days. She has had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much nearly every day. She has felt tired or having little energy more than half the days. She has had poor appetite or overeaten more than half the days. She has felt bad about herself — or that she am a failure or have let herself or her family down more than half the days. She has had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television more than half the days. She has moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed nearly every day. She has had thoughts that she would be better off dead or of hurting herself in some way nearly every day. Does she have depression? Answer with 'Yes' or 'No' and provide a brief explanation for your answer.
model_completion: Yes.  The symptoms described align closely with the diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) as outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These criteria include:  1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. 2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. 3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. 4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. 5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. 6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. 7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day. 8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. 9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.  The woman described has experienced many of these symptoms for more than half the days over the past two weeks, which suggests she may be suffering from depression. It is important for her to seek a professional evaluation for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.
